column1:
[φι]λ̣ῶ  φιλοῦσα  μὴ  φι =
λοῦσαν.  ἐκράφη  σου
 δακτυλε̣ι̣ς̣. 
 <:vacat>  τί  πόλεμον
 <:vacat>  εἴπεις;  τοῦ  δὲ  σοῦ
 <:vacat>  διώλεσεν̣; ,"1–2. The feminine in the participle φιλοῦσα suggests a female writer (or at least persona), the only demonstrable such case among the graffiti. There is, however, a likely case of female homoerotic desire expressed in Pompeian graffiti, now discussed at length by Milnor, K., Graffiti and the Literary Landscape in Roman Pompeii (2014): 191–223. The Pompeian texts raise complex issues, fully treated by Milnor, about agency and authorship
column2: some of those face us as well in the present graffito, but its more pedestrian and (in the first part) non-literary character may make us more inclined to see in it actual selfexpression by a woman than some would wish to admit in the Pompeian case.

column1: 2. ἐκράφη, κ corrected from χ. Read ἐγράφη. The αν preceding is written in somewhat larger letters than what precedes, which might lead one to consider ἀνεκράφη. But we cannot see how to make acceptable Greek of μὴ φίλους, so both grammar and sense seem to support the reading printed. That, of course, points to a female object of the love of the female writer/ persona in line 1. It is not clear to us if the following three words are the product of the same writer or of a second writer responding in some fashion (cf. note to line 3). The letters seem much the same.

3. Between lambda and sigma the writer’s final intentions are not clear. It appears that (s)he first wrote an eta, then changed that to epsilon-iota. As there is no form δακτυλεις in Greek, it seems most likely that the writer intended δακτύλοις
column2: one might perhaps translate “It was written with your fingers.” But the significance of this is unclear to us.

column1: 4–6. These lines, written as noted in a smaller and somewhat cruder hand, are indented as shown. Whether that is the case because the figure drawn to their left was already in place, we cannot say. They offer a remarkably garbled reminiscence of, or attempt to quote, Euripides, Herc. 1134, τί πόλεμον εἶπας
column3: Herakles has just recovered from madness and found his children dead. For Euripides on the wall at Pompeii, cf. Milnor, K., Graffiti and the Literary Landscape in Roman Pompeii (2014): 233. The concluding nu in line 6 is uncertain and could be a sigma
column4: that would only increase the garbling of the quotation.

Πρυτανικός
ΥΤ̣ΙΝΙ 
ΞΡΑΚ̣ΥΤ 
ΓΕΝΟΣ Ν ,"
1. This seems likely to be the proper name (LGPN 5A 383, citing a patronymic in SEG 34.1124.22 from Ephesos

2. This may represent an attempt to write a form of Ὑγῖνος, but the ending does not belong to that declension, and there is no sign of anything following iota. It could be the feminine Ὑγίνη, although this is not to our knowledge attested in Asia Minor.
3. It is difficult to find any sense in this line.
4. Presumably γένος
column2: to the right of the nu no further traces are visible.

[---] Ι̣ΛΕΙΠΟ +++++[---],"1. φιλεῖν and Φιλεῖνος both seem possible in principle
column2: the letter after omicron looks most like a tiny rho without tail, but sigma is more likely given its scale and position
column3: it seems too curved for iota.

column1: 2. ὀφίλ[ειν, read ὀφείλειν, is possible. But φιλεῖνὁ Φιλ[εῖνος seems equally plausible","Basilica of the Agora of Smyrna, Izmir, Turkey",,Uncertain,charcoal,Greek,,"AGP-SMYTP0771, The Ancient Graffiti Project, <

ἐμήσθη Χα̣[---]
 τῆς  καλῆς̣  κ̣υ̣λίας
 εὐτύχει Χαρίτων̣
 μετ̣ὰ Ὑιείνου,"1. Read ἐμνήσθη
column2: we owe the reading to Angelos Chaniotis. It is most often construed with active meaning, taking a genitive object. What follows is presumably the beginning of the woman’s name
column3: Χάρις or one of its derivatives, one supposes. This makes it attractive to take line 2 together with it. But there is then no stated subject: “He remembered (e.g.) Charis the beautiful lady.” The verb can also have passive meaning but should then have a nominative subject. Possibly the writer conflated the two constructions, but he may simply have omitted his own name.

column1: 2. Read κυρίας

3–4. “Fare well, Chariton, with Hyginos.” The first iota in Ὑιείνου appears to have been corrected, so that it at present resembles a phi with faint central circle. It would be more attractive to take it as intended for gamma, but there is no sign of the needed horizontal stroke. Whatever the spelling, we take this as a phonetic spelling of Ὑγίνου.","Basilica of the Agora of Smyrna, Izmir, Turkey"," “He remembered (e.g.) Charis the beautiful lady. Fare well, Chariton, with Hyginos.”",Memorial and Greetings,Graffito/incised,Greek,,"AGP-SMYTP0782, The Ancient Graffiti Project, <

ἐλάινος
 ὁ  πᾶσι  φί =
λητος
 ἐλάινε
 χαίροις
 πολλὰ̣
 ἀγαθώτατε,"The first three lines may be rendered “Olive tree, dear to all,” while the last three lines can be taken as “Fare well for a long time, good sir.” But to find ἐλάινε in the vocative in line 4 is surprising. That suggests a personal name
column2: such a name is listed by LGPN 3A.139 from CIL 4.597 (Pompeii) and 5B.132 from Miletos and Perge. It seems likely that a word-play on the identity is intended
column3: if so, one could render the entire graffito as “The olive tree is dear to all
column4: Mr. Olive, fare well for a long time, good sir.”","Basilica of the Agora of Smyrna, Izmir, Turkey",,Greetings,Graffito/incised,Greek,,"AGP-SMYTP0962, The Ancient Graffiti Project, <

column1: εἰ γνώμο = νος τόπος,"Why εἰ stands at the start, we do not know. “The place of the gnomon”: but in what sense of gnomon, is also not clear.","Basilica of the Agora of Smyrna, Izmir, Turkey",“The place of the gnomon.”,Label?,Graffito/incised,Greek,,"AGP-SMYTP0963, The Ancient Graffiti Project, <

ΑΒΓΥΚΦΚ ΨΕΖΗΚ ΕΖ++Κ ,"Apart from the beginning of the alphabet that leads off the first line, it is not evident what the writer intended. The repetition of kappa does not encourage us to think of a scrambled alphabet in one of the known exercise types used in teaching: reversed, last paired with first, skipping fixed intervals. More promising might be the chalinoi, “alphabets in scrambled order which joined together sequences of letters that were difficult to pronounce” (Cribiore, R., Writing, teachers, and students in Graeco-Roman Egypt (1996): 39), although this does not resemble a known example. There are many other surface scratches, and it is not clear if some are random or part of one of the graffiti identified here.","Basilica of the Agora of Smyrna, Izmir, Turkey",,Alphabetical exercise,Graffito/incised,Greek,,"AGP-SMYTP1001, The Ancient Graffiti Project, <

 τώπος (:τόπος),"3. Not much is visible of the second sigma of Ἀσίας, but it seems syntactically unavoidable.
4. A horizontal trench has been cut in the plaster to eliminate whatever was originally written here.

5–6. φυλάξε = φυλάξαι? Perhaps following that we should read ὑπ̣οζυ|γόκαμε̣ν̣ (l. ὑπεζυγώκαμεν), requiring two phonetic errors to get an acceptable perfect form of the unattested compound ὑποζυγόω (the simplex is known).","Basilica of the Agora of Smyrna, Izmir, Turkey",,Uncertain,Graffito/incised,Greek,,"AGP-SMYTP1004, The Ancient Graffiti Project, <

ΑΛΛΑ ΛΕΓ ̣
 πολλὰ Λ++++,"1. Aeolic or Doric for ἐξαίφνης, but also occurring in Attic texts (LSJ). Cf. T27.2, ἐν τάχει. As this also concerns eyes (see line 2), this is probably a healing inscription. It is conceivable that εὐξάμενος (or εὐξαμένη?) follows: “As soon as I prayed…”

3. Whether ἀλλά or ἄλλα is not clear. Then probably a form of λέγω.","Basilica of the Agora of Smyrna, Izmir, Turkey",,Healing Inscription,charcoal,Greek,,"AGP-SMYT00122, The Ancient Graffiti Project, <

Θεαγένης
 <:vacat>  νεικητ(ής),"

1. Theagenes, the deified Thasian boxer and pankratiast, is the subject of Pausanias 6.11.2–9.  The name is very common throughout the Greek world, but its use here suggests that it might have been adopted by a professional boxer or pankratiast in order to associate himself with the luster of his namesake.
","Basilica of the Agora of Smyrna, Izmir, Turkey","“Theagenes, victor!”",Praise of an Athlete,charcoal,Greek,,"AGP-SMYT00125, The Ancient Graffiti Project, <

ΚΩΝΤ̣Ρ̣,"There is no blank space to the left of the letters, where the head stands. It is possible that the word is abbreviated or continued in a second line, now invisible, in which case it presumably is intended as a noun beginning in κοντρο-, with reference to the nearby head, probably κοντροκυνήγιος. See T25.5 for discussion.
","Basilica of the Agora of Smyrna, Izmir, Turkey",,Label?,charcoal,Greek,,"AGP-SMYT00126, The Ancient Graffiti Project, <
τ̣άφος ,"
We do not know what “burial” or “grave” can signify here, without any further indications.
","Basilica of the Agora of Smyrna, Izmir, Turkey",“Burial” or “grave”,Uncertain,charcoal,Greek,,"AGP-SMYT00128, The Ancient Graffiti Project, <

οβ ,"Cf. T16.2, T28.2, and TP71.1. This could be the numeral 72, but οξ nearby (T15.6), which cannot be a numeral, suggests rather the start of a word. Greek offers only a few options, however, none obviously suitable. Λειοντισ[ ]  [ εὑ]=
ρὼν  μοιχο[---]
 κατέκτανε [---],"The last preserved letter is definitely sigma rather than omicron. The participle shows that the name is not the feminine Λεοντίς, but either Λεόντι(ο)ς  or Λεοντίσκος can be intended. Both names are moderately common in Ionia and elsewhere in Asia Minor (see LGPN 5A 265, 5B 256), but only the second is known so far at Smyrna.

2. As the length of the lacuna is not determinable, it is not obvious whether we should restore only a nu or imagine something more. At a minimalist restoration, Λεοντίσκος εὑ|ρὼν μοιχὸν| κατέκτανε αὐτόν?. But an adverb could easily be added in line 2.","Basilica of the Agora of Smyrna, Izmir, Turkey","Leontis[kos?], finding an adulterer, killed [him].",Scurrilous Allegation,charcoal,Greek,,"AGP-SMYT00061, The Ancient Graffiti Project, <

〚[---------]〛 [----]+ΑΠΕ+++[---] ++η̣ τὴν Βαιτη[ν] καὶ ἀφανίσ[ῃ---] <:vacat> τὸ ἔργ[ο]ν̣ τῷ̣ δήμῳ̣ [---] [ἐ]ὰν δὲ καὶ καταπείνῃ μηδὲν[---] <:vacat> ΜΗ[---],"If nothing more is lost at right than a letter, then we may take ἀφανίσ[ῃ], | τὸ ἔργον τῷ δήμῳ continuously, in the sense of “whoever destroys the work to the detriment of the people.” The work may be the fountain that housed the outflow from the spring. This would (on our view) explain the reference to Baite immediately before. On line 4, cf. T8.1, line 4 and note. How the phrase concludes is not evident. We are (as with T8.1) indebted to Angelos Chaniotis for valuable suggestions.","Basilica of the Agora of Smyrna, Izmir, Turkey",,Orders and threats,charcoal,Greek,,"AGP-SMYT00095, The Ancient Graffiti Project, <

er ,"1. One would perhaps read Ou[a]l[erius or Ou[a]l[ens
column2: the form would represent the Greek rendering of a Latin name turned back into Latin, perhaps a sign of a Hellenophone writer with little Latin but the alphabet
column3: cf. also the note to l. 2.

column1: 2. The traces after euseb look most like Greek ην. In line 3, the letter after b also looks as if it could be an eta. ΑΥ̣Ρ[-]Λ̣[--]Υ̣,"The individual lines of this graffito are intelligible, but connections between them are essentially speculative, making a connected translation impossible. “Silence” in line 1 can stand by itself, and lines 2–3 can be understood as “the place of the child (or slave).” For the rest, things seem disconnected.

8. Αὐρ[η]λ[ίο]υ is evidently attractive, but there is no trace of incision where eta would be required.","Basilica of the Agora of Smyrna, Izmir, Turkey",,Uncertain,Graffito/incised,Greek,,"AGP-SMYTP0841, The Ancient Graffiti Project, <

ΑΠΟΛΟΛΕΙ ζήτημα,"This is the beginning of a riddle, of which whatever else was written is now lost under the new layer of plaster applied just below it (cf. T8.1). It is possible also that nothing more was written. cf. T28.1. ἀπόλωλε is a possible interpretation, but the apparent iota in the last circle is puzzling. as it stands at the extreme left of the available space inside the circle, perhaps nu was intended or written but now mostly lost. We do not know why the letters are written inside circles.","Basilica of the Agora of Smyrna, Izmir, Turkey",,Riddle,charcoal,Greek,,"AGP-SMYT00082, The Ancient Graffiti Project, <

column1: 2. The letter before epsilon does not seem to be gamma.
3. One should perhaps divide –σα πατρός.
4. The penultimate letter appears to have two hastas, as eta or nu, but we have not found a
convincing reading. There is more than ordinary space between pi and epsilon, but no traces.
5–6. The vertical lines indicate where the text crosses the bevel edge.

[ὀφθα]λμοὺς +[---]
[---]  [ε]ὐχαρειστῶ  τῇ [Βαίτῃ] [---]
[--]   ̣θ̣ειῶδ’  ἀγῶνα σ++
[--]  ὑγείᾳ,"The lacuna at right is of uncertain size and could be larger than indicated here.
1. θ, as the beginning of a form (perhaps passive participle) of θεραπεύω, is possible at the end of the line. The word would have continued, in all likelihood, in the next line.
2. See introduction, pp. 44–45, for (the) Baite. Read ε]ὐχαριστῶ.

3. If θειῶδ’ is correctly read, it might indicate that a contest had imperial sanction or was being held in connection with the imperial cult. At the end, read σοι?","Basilica of the Agora of Smyrna, Izmir, Turkey",,Record of Healing,charcoal,Greek,,"AGP-SMYT00141, The Ancient Graffiti Project, <

ὁ̣φ̣θ̣αλμούς
Α++Ε
+++++ισα,"1. It is impossible to say if this is an example of just the word “eyes” being used in thanksgiving for healing, or if some more substantial syntactic framework was provided.
2. There may have been other letters to left or right, now completely faded.

3. ἐ̣π̣ύ̣γ̣ισα is not impossible. If that is the reading, the suspicion that these lines are not all connected is confirmed.","Basilica of the Agora of Smyrna, Izmir, Turkey",,Record of Healing,charcoal,Greek,,"AGP-SMYT00143, The Ancient Graffiti Project, <

- - - - - - +[-]+ΠΟΤΑΙ Ι̣ΔΕΙΝ ΔΕΣΟΥ++ +++++Ν ,"There are also 2–3 lines of letters about 2.5 cm high on the beveled edge of this pier, none of which has been read. In line 1, cf. perhaps the unexplained ΚΑΤΑΠΟΤΑ in T13.3. There does not appear to be anything missing at left, where the pier would have allowed another letter or two. The end of line 1 is faint and squeezed in. It is tempting to interpret lines 2–3 as ἰδεῖν δὲ σοῦ, but further context is elusive.","Basilica of the Agora of Smyrna, Izmir, Turkey",,Uncertain,charcoal,Greek,,"AGP-SMYT01510, The Ancient Graffiti Project, <

Πι̣+++ευδον++ ἐπῆλθε̣ν̣,"1. The unread portion consists entirely, as far as is now visible, of vertical strokes. We have not been able to combine these satisfactorily into a sequence of letters. The letter before epsilon might be pi, suggesting a form of σπεύδω.","Basilica of the Agora of Smyrna, Izmir, Turkey",,Uncertain,charcoal,Greek,,"AGP-SMYT00293, The Ancient Graffiti Project, <

ολοπληθος ,"The letters are all clumsily made, and we have debated whether they are letters at all. The word πλῆθος is, however, highly plausible in this context, where spectators appear in D28.8 and perhaps a spectator in D29.3. There is no compound word ὁλοπλῆθος known, and it seems more prudent to suppose ὅλο(ν) πλῆθος (“the whole people”) than to invent a new word.","Basilica of the Agora of Smyrna, Izmir, Turkey",,Uncertain-Label?,charcoal,Greek,,"AGP-SMYT00298, The Ancient Graffiti Project, <

ὑπ’ ὀψὲ ὄρη Πάρις 
ΠΕ++Ε+ΟΡΕΦ[---]
χρυσο̣[---],"1. One may be tempted to see here a garbled reminiscence of Quintus Smyrnaeus, Posthomerica 10.207: ὀψὲ δέ οἰ ἐπόρουσε Πάρις. But Quintus is probably too late for this to be a plausible explanation
column2: we cannot offer any better one.

column1: The first graffito is written over, or is overwritten by the second one.

Τίτος,"The Roman praenomen Titus is not particularly common in Asia used by itself as a personal name rather than as part of the Roman tria nomina, and LGPN 5A 434 cites no examples from Smyrna
column2: cf. also 5B 410 for additional cases in Caria, Lycia, and Cilicia. No other names follow.","Basilica of the Agora of Smyrna, Izmir, Turkey",,Signature,Graffito/incised,Greek,,"AGP-SMYTP0682, The Ancient Graffiti Project, <

column1:
- - - - - -
+++[--]+[-]++++[---]
ταθίου  καὶ πρωτο +[---]
 ε̣ὐχόμεθα  ε̣ὐτυχεῖ[ν]
 μετὰ  ἡμῶν.  εὐτύχ[ει]
Σ̣αβεῖνε  μετὰ Εὐστα =
〚ΥΤΩ〛θίου.  <:vacat> 
 εὐθόμεθα (:εὐχόμεθα)  σὲ  εὐτυχεῖ[ν]
 μετὰ  ὑμ̣ῶν (:ἡμῶν)
 πολλ<sup>ο</sup>ῖς ἔτεσιν. ,"1. Only the bottoms of letters are visible.

2. Presumably this is another appearance of the name Eustathios, although that does not give a good syllabic division. The appearance of this name, common in the fourth century and later, may suggest a relatively late date, although LGPN 4 137 lists one example from Thessalonike dated as early as the second to third century. Perhaps simply πρῶτον̣ at the end, but there are other possibilities.

5. Only the top tip of sigma ligaturing into alpha is visible at the start, but we cannot see any other possible interpretation of these letters. A referee remarks that Sabinus is a common gladiatorial stage name (thinking perhaps of Messalina’s lover of that name in Cassius Dio 60.28) and suggests that the good wishes here might be for success in gladiatorial games. But Eustathios hardly seems to fit that hypothesis, and Sabinus is in general a very common name and not characteristic of slaves.
7. Read εὐχόμεθα.

8. Read (as in line 3) ἡμῶν.","Basilica of the Agora of Smyrna, Izmir, Turkey","“. . . [Eus]tathios (?) and first . . . We pray to have good fortune with us. Good luck, Sabinus with Eustathios. We pray that you may have good fortune with us for many years.”",Good wishes,charcoal,Greek,,"AGP-SMYTP1281, The Ancient Graffiti Project, <

column1:
[---]  ἐ̣ξ̣ώ̣λη  σου
[---]  ἀ̣δε̣λ̣φὸς̣  ἐξώλη
 [τῷ]  [ἀναγιν]ώ̣σ̣κοντι
[---Τ]ροφίμη
[---] +ΝΕΘΗΣ 
[---] +ΑΙ ΕΝΟΗΓΑΣ 
Θάλλος,"

1–2. ἐξώλης, “utterly destroyed,” is common, with numerous examples in the epigraphy of Asia Minor in phrases like ἐξώλης εἴη καὶ τὰ αὐτοῦ πάντα or ἐξώλης εἴη καὶ αὐτὸς καὶ γένος τὸ ἐκείνου (see PHI Greek Inscriptions for instances, and the comprehensive treatment in Strubbe, J. H. M., Arai epitymbioi: imprecations against desecrators of the grave in the Greek epitaphs of Asia Minor, a catalogue (1997). It is not completely clear if it should be accusative in line 1 as divided here, but the form in line 2 certainly is. The overall syntax is not evident, but it seems likely that destruction is being wished on the reader in line 3. There is a long history of graffiti wishing various ills on their reader
column2: cf., e.g., Milnor, K., Graffiti and the Literary Landscape in Roman Pompeii (2014): 75.

column1: 4. Trophime is common in Asia Minor, with two examples in LGPN 5A 435 from Smyrna.
The second graffito could also be the common noun θαλλός, referring to the olive shoots of which crowns were made. But the name is common in Asia (LGPN 5A 209, 5B 190) and seems more likely.
","Basilica of the Agora of Smyrna, Izmir, Turkey",,Name,charcoal,Greek,,"AGP-SMYT00331, The Ancient Graffiti Project, <

ψωλή,"The word, written here over D11.5, a drawing of a phallus, is defined by lsJ as membrum virile praeputio retracto. But this is too specific and genteel
column2: aristophanes’ usage (Aves 560, Lys. 979) does not support it. Modern Greek usage, no doubt little different, is defined in Babiniotis 1988: 2022 as το ανδρικό μόριο, το πέος and marked as vulgar: “prick” would be a good english rendering. an excellent parallel to our text is furnished by SEG 49.1385a, where the word is written over a drawing of a phallus from a latrine in rome.","Basilica of the Agora of Smyrna, Izmir, Turkey",,Label of phallus,charcoal,Greek,,"AGP-SMYT00111, The Ancient Graffiti Project, <

θελητὴ
 ἡ  κυρία,"1. Usage of θελητός is overwhelmingly Christian, but it occurs (rarely) in the Septuagint and once in Epictetus (Diss. ab Arr. 4.1.101). We have found no parallel for this occurrence with κυρία. Chaniotis (SEG) prefers a non-Christian interpretation.

2. The word κυρία appears also in T20.3.2 and 5 (if our interpretation of κυλείας there is correct), but the context is far from clear and does not seem to be the same as here.","Basilica of the Agora of Smyrna, Izmir, Turkey",“The lady is desired (?).”,Uncertain (see figure on Tp100.1),Graffito/incised,Greek,,"AGP-SMYTP1002, The Ancient Graffiti Project, <

ΗΧΑ+Η ,"3–4. The generic usage of ἀνατολή to mean “the East” is well attested, but the numerous parallels in the graffiti to civic boasting suggest that the sense here is more specific. The only parallel
before the sixth century known to us for a use of Ἀνατολή to refer to Asia Minor or perhaps more specifically to the province of Asia, however, is Diocletian’s Edict of Maximum Prices.

5–6. These lines are written in substantially smaller letters than lines 1–4.","Basilica of the Agora of Smyrna, Izmir, Turkey","“Greetings Tralleis, first of Anatolia (or ‘of the East’).”",Acclamation,charcoal,Greek,,"AGP-SMYTP1051, The Ancient Graffiti Project, <

1. Scanty as the traces are, they suggest the possibility of reading [φιλῶ] ἧς ὁ [ἀρι|θμὸς] ψν

. There may be a trace before psi in line 2, but this is not certain. If this interpretation is correct, it indicates a love object whose name was valued isopsephistically at 750 or at a number in the range 751–759. There are at least seven feminine names in LGPN 5A in this range. Cf. Bagnall, R. S. et al., Graffiti from the Basilica in the Agora of Smyrna (2016): 48.
","Basilica of the Agora of Smyrna, Izmir, Turkey",,Love Declaration?,charcoal,Greek,,"AGP-SMYT00127, The Ancient Graffiti Project, <

Ἀρτεμιδώρου
 Ζμυρναίου (:Σμυρναίου)
 ἰσόψηφα
 κύριος ω 
 πίστις ω ,"1. Artemidoros is among the most popular names at Smyrna, as one can see from LGPN 5A.71, where it occupies nearly a column.

4–5. Both κύριος (20 + 400 + 100 + 10 + 70 + 200) and πίστις (80 + 10 + 200 + 300 + 10 + 200) in fact add up to 800 as isopsephisms. For the Christian character of the inscription, see Bagnall, R., Everyday Writing in the Graeco-Roman East (2011): 45.","Basilica of the Agora of Smyrna, Izmir, Turkey",,Names and isopsephisms,Graffito/incised,Greek,,"AGP-SMYTP1003, The Ancient Graffiti Project, <

κοντροκυνή= <:vacat> γις,"1–2. Presumably for *κοντροκυνήγιος, a wild-beast hunter with a pike. LSJ lists κοντροκυνηγέσιον, citing IGRR 4.1632 and SEG 6.608, where L. Robert refers to his discussion of IGRR 3.360 in Rev.Arch. 30 (1929) 29–31 = Opera Minora Selecta 1.696–698. There he comments on the use of σιδηροκόντρα. There are no literary occurrences recorded in TLG. Cf. the fragmentary T12.6 for another possible occurrence at Smyrna.","Basilica of the Agora of Smyrna, Izmir, Turkey",,Label,charcoal,Greek,,"AGP-SMYT00255, The Ancient Graffiti Project, <

ζῇς ζῇς ἔψυγμαι,"This comes from ψύχω. Cf. T15.2 and T29.5. “I have been chilled!” Is the reference to the cooling shade of the basement level? The case of T29.5, however, where it is written on a testicle, suggests that a sexual meaning (or double-entendre?) may be intended, whether that refers to the cooling of emotion or more specifically to the loss of an erection. There appears to be one stroke after the word, whether connected with it cannot be determined.","Basilica of the Agora of Smyrna, Izmir, Turkey",“May you live!”,Good wishes,"Pictura, Litt. Scariph.",Greek,,"AGP-SMYT00211, The Ancient Graffiti Project, <

[φιλῶ] [ο]ὗ̣ ἀ̣ριθμὸς τνα,"If the reading of upsilon is correct, as we think, this is the one example of a love-message among these graffiti in which the object is male. The two male heads adjacent (DP54.1) suggest that the writer is also.","Basilica of the Agora of Smyrna, Izmir, Turkey",“I love a man whose number is 351.”,"Declaration of love, isopsephism",Graffito/incised,Greek,,"AGP-SMYT00422, The Ancient Graffiti Project, <

Ἡγεῖνος  εἶπ̣[εν]
 τ̣ὸν̣  ὀφθαλμ[ὸν]
 ἐν  τάχει  ἐθαραπεύ̣[θην],"1. Read Ὑγῖνος. The name is well represented in Ionia and Caria, see LGPN 5A.440, 5B.418, with an example in the former from Smyrna.

3. The mention of the swiftness of the cure is intended to point to the power of the divinity who effected the cure. Chaniotis, A. 2009a. “Ritual Performances of Divine Justice: The Epigraphy of Confession, Atonement, and Exaltation in Roman Asia Minor.” In H. M. Cotton, R. G. Hoyland, J. J. Price, and D. J. Wasserstein, eds., From Hellenism to Islam: Cultural and Linguistic Change in the Roman Near East: 115–53. Cambridge. discusses this phenomenon, citing examples. We quote from his email of 29 January 2015: “In an epitaph, Lord the Almighty is asked to punish a murderer fast (SEG 50 (2000), 1233 (Neoklaudiopolis, AD 237): Κύριε Παντοκράτωρ· σὺ μὲ ἔκτισες, κακὸς δέ με ἄνθρωπος ἀπώλεσεν· ἐγδίκησόν με ἐν τάχι). The god is invited in a subtle way to prove his endless power not only by punishing the murderer, but also by inflicting the punishment fast (ἐν τάχι). This is a strategy known from magical texts. In order to provoke the anger of the gods and demons, the magician often urges them to act fast (ἤδη ἤδη, ταχύ ταχύ). And in a confession inscription (Petzl, Beichtinschriften no. 69), the power of the god is shown by the fact that he punishes Tatias and her son within a day (μονημέρῳ κολάσει ἀπηλλάγη).”
","Basilica of the Agora of Smyrna, Izmir, Turkey","“Hyginos said, ‘My eye was quickly healed’.”",Record of healing,charcoal,Greek,,"AGP-SMYT00272, The Ancient Graffiti Project, <

column1:
Pompe〈:vacat〉 IV a(ssibus) III S(emis) P(ondo?) lard(i) a(ssibus) III Vinum a(sse) S(emis) Casium a(sse) S(emis) Oleum a(sse) I Panem a(ssibus) I S(emis) Suar(ium?) a(ssibus) IIII ,"Textus secundum (8). Contulit Sypniewski ad schedas Della Corte apud Institutum Getty a. 2018. Benefiel et Sypniewski (AGP) a. 2019 contulerunt et emendaverunt apud apographum ex Instituto Getty et apographa (1) et (2). Lapsu tectorii periit (8)
v. 1: A pro A(ssibus) exstat in schedis Della Corte et tunc in transcriptione sed non in apographo apud (1), littera A caret in apographo et transcriptione apud (2), sed finis versus 1 pretium dare videtur.
v. 1: POMPE(IIS) IV(?) A III S (1) - POMPE(IIS) IV(...?) (assibus) III S(emis) (2)
vv. 3-4: sequimur lectionem quae clare in aprographis apud (1) et (2) videtur: A(sse) S(emis) (8).
VINVM A S / CASIVM A S (1) - VINVM A(sse) I / CASIVM A(sse) I (2)
v. 6: PANEM A II (1) - PANEM A(ssibus) II S(emis) (2) - PANEM A(ssibus) I S(emis) (8), secundum apographa apud (1) et (2).
Alter index ciborum cum pretiis in stria 13 eiusdem columnae ad EDR128734 invenitur.
Infra EDR167447 et supra EDR128290 et EDR167446.
Permulti titulti, quorum multi imagines sunt, in hac columna inveniuntur: EDR127405, EDR167451, EDR167453 (stria 5), EDR168101, EDR167581, et EDR127191 (stria 7), EDR127829, EDR127830, EDR127831, EDR128660 (stria 8), EDR128661 et EDR128733 (stria 9), EDR127828 et EDR128734 (stria 13), EDR128662 (stria 14), EDR127081 (stria 15), EDR128738 et EDR167583 (stria 16), EDR128663 (stria 10, 12, 15-16, 17).","Pompei (Napoli), Regio II.7.1, Campus ad amphitheatrum, col. P(ubli) Pro= pesi cuntus. Verpa que (:quae) is= tuc leges. 〈:vacat〉 Non es fiden= ter, script= o (:scriptor) ((:phallus)),"Textus secundum (5), mensurae secundum (7). Contulerunt Zimmermann Damer et Benefiel (AGP) a. 2019.
Tectorium nunc maxime corrosum, sed vestigia adhuc videntur a. 2019.
v. 5: II pro littera E scriptum
vv. 8-12: scripti alia manu lectoris cuiusdam (5)
v. 3: Legerim CVNTVS, pro CONTVS scriptum (5)
v. 4: VERPA (E)S (1), VERP(a) ES (2), VERPA (5)
v. 5: QVI (2), QVE pro QVAE (5)
v. 7: LEGES pro LEGIS (2)
vv. 8-12: NON ES (= ne sis) / FIDEN/TER (pro fidens). / SCRIPT/O. (2)
vv. 1-13: P. PROPESICVNIVS (SCRIBIT): VERPA (E)S QVI ISTVC LEGES (pro legis)! NON ES (=ne sis) FIDENS (=ne fidas) SCRIPTO! (1)
vv. 1-13: P. PROPESICVNIVS (nomen fictum?) (SCRIBIT): VERP(A) ES QVI ISTVC LEGES (pro legis). NON ES (=ne sis) FIDENTER (pro fidens) SCRIPTO. (2)
vv. 1-13: POPIDIVS/ SECVNDVS/ VERPA (E)S/ QVI IS/TVC / LEGES / NON ES / PEDICA/TOR / SCRIPT/E (3)

vestigia in tectorio corroso adhuc a. 2019 extant.

Permulti tituli crebri in hac columna inveniuntur:
In stria 5, SABIDIA / ABONIVS (EDR167690) et gladiator (EDR167542).
In stria 6, tres imagines et unus titulus inscripti sunt: caput hominis ad sin. (EDR167547), COPO (EDR168185), hic titulus, et scyphus (EDR123458).
In stria 8, alterum caput hominis ad sin. (EDR167544).
In stria 13, X (EDR167692) et et QVIBVS (EDR167691).
Etiam in eadem columna, in striis 14-16 MARE (EDR167694)

column1:
((:crux orbiculis ad extremum bracchiorum)),"Textus secundum et mensurae (6). Contulerunt Sypniewski et Benefiel (AGP) a. 2019.
Locus inventionis in stria 14 secundum (5)-(6), aliter [in stria 15] (1) (2).
v. 1: orbiculis additis postea et incisis subtiliter (6)
Signum geometricum (3) (6), aliter (1) (2).
A Della Corte signum Christianum creditur: una croce dai bracci incurvati a forma di Rho, la quale potrebbe esser ritenuta pure essa come un simbolo cristiano (1). Quattuor brachia crucis in speciam litterae ρ
column2:
torta sunt (2),
Sed Varone prudentior videtur: lncerto è intanto se di Rho si tratti (il loro andamento è retrogrado) e comunque in ogni caso è arduo pervenire al significato di tale scritta (3).
Et, orbiculi postea additi sunt: Orbiculi ad extremum brachiorum alia et tenuiore cuspide tempore sequenti incisi sunt (5).

Chloe,"Textus et mensurae secundum (2), periit (7). Contulerunt Sypniewski et Benefiel (AGP) a. 2019
column2:
vestigia in tectorio corroso adhuc a. 2019 extant.

Nomen Chloe sexies in campo ad amphitheatrum invenitur: col. XXXI (EDR127423), col. LXI (EDR127817), col. LXII in tribus striis contiguis (4-6) et in eadem altitudine (hic titulus, EDR128116, EDR128118), et col. LXIII (EDR127368).
Chloe erat actor (3),(5) aut meretrix (4),(6).
Chloe cum Actio Aniceto (alibi dominus scaenicorum appellatur) in Regio VII.6.35 (CIL 04, 01646, et add. p. 210) nominatur (3).

((:galea gladiatoria cristata)),"Textus secundum (5), mensura secundum (3). Contulerunt Benefiel, Sypniewski, et Damer (AGP) a. 2019.
Della Corte (1)-(2) putavit hanc galeam partem figurae gladiatoris esse, sed pars inferior figurae, designata subligaculum, est vere vela de titulo EDR147923.

((:caput hominis ad sin.)),"Textus secundum (2), mensurae secundum (4). Contulerunt Sypniewski et Benefiel (AGP) a. 2019.
Titulus descriptus sic: busto virile a sinistra (1), iuvenis caput ad sin. (2)

Permulti tituli crebri in hac columna inveniuntur:
In stria 5, SABIDIA / ABONIVS (EDR167690) et gladiator (EDR167542).
In stria 6, tres imagines et unus titulus inscripti sunt: caput hominis ad sin. (EDR167547), COPO (EDR168185), clipeus (EDR123457), et scyphus (EDR123458).
In stria 8, hic titulus.
In stria 13, X (EDR167692) et et QVIBVS (EDR167691).
Etiam in eadem columna, in striis 14-16 MARE (EDR167694)
column2: in stria 15, A. LICINIVS  (EDR167695) et IVCVDVS / MALE CALA (EDR167696)
column3: in stria 16, caput hominis ad sin. (EDR167550)
column4: in stria 17 textus ad perpendiculum qui non legitur (EDR167697).","Pompei (Napoli), Regio II.7.1, Campus ad amphitheatrum, col. LXXXIX, stria 8",,Drawing of a face,Graffito/incised,,8713,"AGP-EDR167544, The Ancient Graffiti Project, <

litt. alt.: 1-1,3
Nomen scriptum ad dexteram imaginis, quasi in semicirculo in spatio reliquo striae ante fasciolam.
Titulus descriptus sic: Un sorridente bustino giovanile in terza a sinistra (1), herma iuvenilis prospiciens quo subter nomen in semicirculum scriptum (2)
Hic titulus unicum exemplum nominis in litteris Graecis in Italia est. In litteris Latinis nomen ut Esichus (EDR148297, Puteoli), Esychus (EDR100292, Liternum), Hesycus (EDR101263, Roma), aut Hesychus (EDR108964, Herculaneum) scribitur. Nomen Hesychus apud Tabulas Pompeianas Sulpiciorum invenitur (EDR075458, EDR076977).
In eadem columna EDR167567 et EDR127406 (stria 4)

column2: E,Textus et mensurae secundum (1),"Pompei (Napoli), Regio II.4.1",,,Graffito/incised,Latin,10114b,"AGP-EDR180463, The Ancient Graffiti Project, <

(?) leviter incisa est. Utrum hi versus ad quinque versus infra pertineant dubitatur.
Pars II: unus de notissimis titulis Pompeianis. Saepe testimonium christianorum esse creditur, sed unum exemplum de multis ludis quadratis verborum (18),(21). Cf. CIL 04, 08297.
Pars II, v. 4: multi quid AREPO significet explicare conati sunt, e.g. verbum celticum (11), sententia in litteris singulis condita: A R(erum) E(xtremarum) P(rincipio) O(mni) (6).
Pars III: etiam L M O legi potest (23) et levius ceteris, ut videtur in imagine apud (22). Utrum hic versus ad quinque versus supra pertineat dubitatur.
Supra EDR127824 (SAVTRAN VALE). Idem nomen in stria 10 invenitur (EDR127823, SAVTRAN VA).
In eadem columna EDR127816, EDR127817, EDR127818 (stria 5)

mensura altitudinis secundum (4). Contulerunt Sypniewski et Benefiel (AGP) a. 2019.

Permulti tituli crebri in hac columna inveniuntur:
In stria 5, hic titulus et gladiator, infra (EDR167542)
In stria 6, tres imagines et unus titulus inscripti sunt: caput hominis ad sin. (EDR167547), COPO (EDR168185), clipeus (EDR123457), et scyphus (EDR123458).
In stria 8, alterum caput hominis ad sin. (EDR167544).
In stria 13, X (EDR167692) et QVIBVS (EDR167691).
Etiam in eadem columna, in striis 14-16, MARE (EDR167694)
column3: in stria 15, A. LICINIVS  (EDR167695) et IVCVDVS / MALE CALA (EDR167696)

In stria 8, alterum caput hominis ad sin. (EDR167544).

Nomen Chloe sexies in campo ad amphitheatrum invenitur: col. XXXI (EDR127423), col. LXI (EDR127817), col. LXII in tribus striis contiguis (4-6) et in eadem altitudine (EDR127428, EDR128116, EDR128118), et col. LXIII (hic titulus).
Chloe erat actor (3),(5) aut meretrix (4),(6).
Chloe cum Actio Aniceto (alibi dominus scaenicorum appellatur) in Regio VII.6.35 (CIL 04, 01646, et add. p. 210) nominatur (3).

vv. 1-3: Pacatus (athleta?) (1)-(2), quod Della Corte credit hoc aedificium esse locum athletis. Sed HIC MANSIT intellegi possit ut hic, oppido Pompeiis, non tantum hic, in hoc aedificio, et CVM SVIS possit intellegi ut cum familia sua. (3)
In duabus striis sed non fasciola interveniente scriptus est.
Nomen Pacatus fortasse etiam in campo ad amphitheatrum invenitur in col. XXIII (EDR128059: VOCONIVS PACA VIXILLV).

column2:

v. 1: O HLO = CHLO(E)? Prima littera O vel C cum linea extranea.
vv. 1-2: CHLOE / VA (1) sed lectio dubia est.

Nomen Chloe sexies in campo ad amphitheatrum invenitur: col. XXXI (EDR127423), col. LXI (EDR127817), col. LXII in tribus striis contiguis (4-6) et in eadem altitudine (EDR127428, EDR128116, EDR128716), col. LXIII (EDR127368).
Chloe erat actor (3),(5) aut meretrix (4),(6).
Chloe cum Actio Aniceto (alibi dominus scaenicorum appellatur) in Regio VII.6.35 (CIL 04, 01646, et add. p. 210) nominatur (3).

Permulti tituli crebri in hac columna inveniuntur:
In stria 5, SABIDIA / ABONIVS (EDR167690) et gladiator (EDR167542).
In stria 6, tres imagines et unus titulus inscripti sunt: caput hominis ad sin. (EDR167547), hic titulus, clipeus (EDR123457), et scyphus (EDR123458).
In stria 8, alterum caput hominis ad sin. (EDR167544).
In stria 13, X (EDR167692) et QVIBVS (EDR167691).
Etiam in eadem columna, in striis 14-16 MARE (EDR167694)
